sourcesContent:
var tao =  [
  {passage : {
        chapterNum : "1",
        poem : " A dao that may be spoken is not the enduring Dao. A name that may be named is not an enduring name. </br>"+
"No names – this is the beginning of heaven and earth. Having names – this is the mother of the things of the world.</br>"+
"Make freedom from desire your constant norm; thereby you will see what is subtle. Make having desires your constant norm; thereby you will see what is manifest. ;</br>"+
"These two arise from the same source but have different names. Together they may be termed ‘the mysterious’..</br>"+
"Mystery and more mystery: the gate of all that is subtle. </br>"
    }},
    
   {passage : {
        chapterNum : "2",
        poem : "All in the world deem the beautiful to be beautiful; it is ugly. All deem the good to be good; it is bad.</br>"+
"What is and what is not give birth to one another, </br>"+
"What is difficult and what is easy complete one another, </br>"+
"Long and short complement one another, </br>"+
"High and low incline towards one another,</br>"+
"Note and noise harmonize with one another,</br>"+
"Before and after follow one another.</br>"+
"Therefore the sage dwells in the midst of non-action (wuwei) and practices the wordless teaching.</br>"+
"Herein arise the things of the world, it does not turn from them; what it gives birth to it does not possess; what it does it does not retain. The achievements complete, it makes no claim to them. Because it makes no claim to them, they never leave it. </br>"
    }},

{passage : {
        chapterNum : "3",
        poem : "Do not honor the worthy. This will keep the people from contention.</br>"+
"Do not prize rare things. This will keep the people from becoming thieves.</br>"+
"Do not display the desirable. The hearts of the people will not be turbulent.</br>"+
"Hence the governance of the sage: Empty their minds and fill their bellies, Weaken their wills and strengthen their bones. </br>"+
 "Always render the people free of knowledge and desire. Ensure that the clever do not dare to act.</br>"+
"Engage in non-action (wuwei) and nothing will go unruled. </br>"
    }},

{passage : {
        chapterNum : "4",
        poem : "The Dao is empty yet you may keep drawing from it as though it could never fill your need. </br>"+
"It is an abyss, like the ancestor of the world of things. </br>"+
" Blunt the point, Undo the tangle, Soften the glare, Join the dust. </br>"+
" Dim, it seems almost to exist. I know not whose child it may be. It seems the forerunner of the Lord. </br>"
    }},


{passage : {
        chapterNum : "5",
        poem : "Heaven and earth are not ren: they treat the things of the world as straw dogs. The sage is not ren: he treats the people as straw dogs. </br>"+
"All between heaven and earth is like a great bellows-- Empty, yet it does not collapse, The more it is moved the more it issues forth. </br>"+
"Many words are soon exhausted; Better to preserve the central. </br>"
    }},

{passage : {
        chapterNum : "6",
        poem : "The spirit of the ravine is undying; it is called the dark vagina. The gateway of the dark vagina is called the root of the world. </br>"+
"Stretching further and further, as though always there; use it, effortless. </br>"
    }},
{passage : {
        chapterNum : "7",
        poem : "Heaven endures; earth long abides. Heaven endures and earth long abides because they do not give birth to themselves. Hence they are long lived.</br>"+
"Hence the sage places his person last, and it comes first; he treats it as something external to him and it endures. </br>"+
   "Does he not employ selflessness? Hence he attains his self-regarding ends. </br>"
    }},

{passage : {
        chapterNum : "8",
        poem : "The best quality/character is like water.</br>"+
   "The water's goodness is that it benefits the myriad things but does not quarrel, and it willingly goes to where others hate,</br>"+
   "Thus it is almost like the Dao.</br>"+
"It is good to be/live on the ground, to deepen a heart, to love people while associating with them.</br>"+
"to keep one's word while talking, to be peace while governing, to do what one is capable of, to act at a fit time.</br>"+
"Because of the non-fighting-over, there will be no problem.</br>"
    }},

{passage : {
        chapterNum : "9",
        poem : "Rather than pour into a cup overflowed, It is better to stop it.</br>"+
   "To hammer and to sharpen, it will not be long to be broken.</br>"+
   "One cannot keep in eternal hiding a hall brimming with riches.</br>"+
   "The man arrogant from enormous wealth buries disaster upon his road.</br>"+
  "When you have achieved your goal, you had better recede: the Dao's way.</br>"
    }},
{passage : {
        chapterNum : "10",
        poem : "Can you focus one's mind on one thought and remine undistracted?</br>"+
"While being fully focused on your vital breath can you make it soft like that of a newborn babe?</br>"+
"While cleaning your inner mirror can you leave it without blemish?</br>"+
"To love people and to govern the country, How not to appoint the Jih/Zhi/wise people?</br>"+
"The gate of the heaven shuts and opens alternately and frequently, How to act like females?</br>"+
"Have known all the causes and effects, How to keep doing only the backlog of things?</br>"+
"Quicken them, feed them, Produce and do not own.</br>"+
"Act and do not claim. Raise and do not rule. This is called profound virtue.</br>"
    }},

{passage : {
        chapterNum : "11",
        poem : "Thirty spokes share a single hub; grasp the nothingness at its center to get the use of the wheel.</br>"+
"Clay is fashioned to make a vessel; grasp the nothingness at the center to get the use of the vessel. </br>"+
"Bore windows and doors to create a room; grasp the nothingness of the interior to get the use of the room.</br>"+
"That which is constitutes what is valuable, but that which is not constitutes what is of use. </br>"
    }},

{passage : {
        chapterNum : "12",
        poem : "The beautiful colours make people's eyes blind,</br>"+
"The appealing music makes people's ears deaf,</br>"+
"The delicious flavours make people's mouth numb,</br>"+
"To indulge in hunting makes people's heart wild,</br>"+
"To pursue rare treasures makes people's behavior improper.</br>"+
"So, as the sage attends to the inner world, not the outer world, Throw away the latter and adopt the former.</br>"
    }},

{passage : {
        chapterNum : "13",
        poem : "Both favour and disgrace bring fear. Great trouble comes from having a body</br>"+
"What is meant by: Both favour and disgrace bring fear? Favour leads to a fear of losing it and disgrace leads to a fear of greater trouble.</br>"+
"What is meant by: Great trouble comes from having a body? The reason you have trouble is that you are self-conscious. No trouble can befall a self-free person.</br>"+
"Therefore, surrender your self-interest. Love others as much as you love yourself. Then you can be entrusted with all things under heaven.</br>"
    }},

{passage : {
        chapterNum : "14",
        poem : "That which is looked at yet never seen is known as invisible,</br>"+
   "That which is listened to yet never heard is known as soundless,</br>"+
   "And that which is grasped yet never touched is known as intangible.</br>"+
"The origin of these three can not be observed, so mix them and form a unity.</br>"+
   "Above, it is not lit; Below, it is not dark.</br>"+
"The Dao cannot be named by common rules, as it returns to its origin,</br>"+
   "It is the shape of the original shape, the image of the original object,This is blur and profound.</br>"+
   "Step forward, cannot see its beginning; Follow it, cannot see its end.</br>"+
"Hold the ancient Dao to know the present things, and thus know the ancient beginnings, This is the principle of the Dao.</br>"
    }},

{passage : {
        chapterNum : "15",
        poem : "Once upon a time, those who knew the Way, were a mysterious and subtle people, Transient yet profound, tranquil yet utterly unfathomable.</br>"+
   "Since they are inexplicable, I can only tell what they seem like: Cautious, as if wading through a winter river, Wary, as if afraid of their own neighbours. Grave, like the courteous house guests.</br>"+
   "Elusive, as of melting ice. Pure and natural, as of unchiseled gems.Wide and open, as of a deep valley.</br>"+
   "Yet mysterious, oh yes, they were like troubled water.</br>"+
   "Who can remain tranquil amidst troubled airs, that calmness may flow from within?</br>"+
   "Who may remain at peace eternal, that motion would yield birth to nature?</br>"+
   "For those who follow the Way, fulfillment has never been their aim.</br>"+
   "Only as they are forever unfulfilled, can such freshness be ever renewed.</br>"
    }},

{passage : {
        chapterNum : "16",
        poem : "Reaching the ultimate of emptiness, deeply guarding stillness, the things of the world arise together; thereby do I watch their return. </br>"+
"The things of the world burst out everywhere, and each returns to its own root. </br>"+
"Returning to the root is called stillness; this is called returning to destiny;</br>"+
"returning to destiny is called constant; knowing the constant is called enlightenment.</br>"+
"Not knowing the constant one acts blindly and ill-omened. </br>"+
"Knowing the constant one can accommodate; accommodation leads to impartiality; impartiality leads to kingliness; kingliness leads to Tian; Tian leads to the Dao.</br>"+
"With the Dao one may endure, and to the end of life one will not be in danger. </br>"
}
},

{passage : {
        chapterNum : "17",
        poem : "Great rulers are hardly known by their subjects,</br>"+
    "Then come those the people draw near and praise,</br>"+
    "Then those the people hold in fear,</br>"+
    "Then those the people revile.</br>"+
    "When one lacks trust, one finds no trust.</br>"+
"Reluctantly, without boasting;</br>"+
"Perform actions, accomplish deeds;</br>"+
"The people will say it happened naturally.</br>"
    }},

{passage : {
        chapterNum : "18",
        poem : "When the Dao is lost, so there arises benevolence and righteousness.</br>"+
"When prudence and wisdom appear, there is great hypocrisy.</br>"+
"When family relations are not right, there is filial piety and paternal affection.</br>"+
"When the state is confused and chaotic, there is loyalty and faithfulness.</br>"
    }},

{passage : {
        chapterNum : "19",
        poem : "Abandon holiness, relinquish prudence; the people will flourish a hundredfold,</br>"+
"Abandon benevolence, relinquish righteousness; and people will return to filial piety and affection.</br>"+
"Abandon cleverness, relinquish gain; and thieves and robbers will not appear.</br>"+
    "As I know such three to be no mere words, Stay true to that which is reliable.</br>"+
    "Recognise simplicity, embrace purity, Lessen the self, diminish desires.</br>"
    }},

{passage : {
        chapterNum : "20",
        poem : "Discard conventional doctrines and be relieved from anxieties.</br>"+
"To assent and to object – how different are they? Beauty and ugliness – what is the distinction between them? </br>"+
"What others fear, one must fear too – how baseless! Far off the mark! </br>"+
"How joyous the mass of people are, as if banqueting on the sacrificed ox, as if mounting a tower in spring – I alone am still, without visible sign, like a new born baby yet to smile, all listless, like one with no home. </br>"+
"The mass of people have more than enough – I alone appear bereft; I, with the mind of a dolt, so slow. </br>"+
"Ordinary men are brilliant – I am dim.</br>"+
"Ordinary men are perceptive – I am closed. </br>"+
"Sudden, like the sea, like a tempest, as though endless, the mass of people all have their means – I alone am obstinate, uncouth. </br>"+
"I alone wish to be different from others, and value feeding from the mother. </br>"
    }},

{passage : {
        chapterNum : "21",
        poem : "Where the greatest Virtue resides, Only the Dao may reveal.</br>"+
"The Tao is shadowy and intangible. Intangible and evasive, and yet within it is a form.</br>"+
"Evasive and intangible, and yet within it is a substance.</br>"+
"Shadowy and dark, and yet within it is a vital force.</br>"+
"This vital force is real and can be relied upon.</br>"+
"From ancient times to the present the Tao’s instructions have not been forgotten.</br>"+
"Through it can be perceived the beginning of the story of life.</br>"+
"How do I know how it was at the beginning of the story of life? Because of what is within me.</br>"
    }},

{passage : {
        chapterNum : "22",
        poem : "Yield and overcome; bend and be straight. Empty out and be full; wear out and be renewed.</br>"+
"Have little and gain; have much and be confused.</br>"+
"Therefore, the True Person embraces the One and becomes a model for all.</br>"+
"Do not look only at yourself, and you will see much.</br>"+
"Do not justify yourself, and you will be distinguished.</br>"+
"Do not brag, and you will have merit</br>"+
"Do not be prideful, and your work will endure.</br>"+
"It is because you do not strive that no one under heaven can strive with you.</br>"+
"The saying of the Old Ones, Yield and Overcome, is not an empty phrase. True wholeness is achieved by blending with life.</br>"
    }},

{passage : {
        chapterNum : "23",
        poem : "Less spoken, words speak for themselves naturally.</br>"+
"Therefore gusts cannot chill the exuberant day,</br>"+
"Showers cannot turn day to dusk. Why is it so?</br>"+
"Even the heaven and earth cannot counter its own force, Let alone people?</br>"+
"Therefore those engaged with the Dao takes pleasure that, The Taught is the Dao,</br>"+
"The Virtuous is the Virtue, The perplexed is perplexity.</br>"+
"At one with the Dao, the Dao is welcoming; At one with Virtue, Virtue be appreciating;</br>"+
"At one with perplexity, perplexity be gratifying.</br>"+
"Lack of belief, Explains the disbelief in this futility.</br>"
    }},

{passage : {
        chapterNum : "24",
        poem : "The person on tiptoe is not steady. The person with legs astride cannot walk</br>"+
"Those who look only at themselves see little.</br>"+
"Those who justify themselves are not distinguished.</br>"+
"Those who brag have no merit.</br>"+
"The work of prideful people will not endure.</br>"+
"From the standpoint of the Tao, these things are excessive food and tumours of the body.</br>"+
"As they bring sickness, followers of the Tao do not linger around them.</br>"
    }},

{passage : {
        chapterNum : "25",
        poem : "Something formless yet complete, existing before heaven and earth.</br>"+
"Silent and limitless, it stands alone and does not change.</br>"+
"Reaching everywhere, it does not tire.</br>"+
"Perhaps it is the Mother of all things under heaven. I do not know its name so I call it “Tao.”</br>"+
"When I have to describe it I call it great. Being great it flows. It flows far away.</br>"+
"Having gone far away, it returns. Therefore, the Tao is great.</br>"+
"Heaven is great. Earth is great. People are also great.</br>"+
"Thus, people constitute one of the four great things of the universe.</br>"+
"People conform to the earth. The earth conforms to heaven.</br>"+
"Heaven conforms to the Tao. The Tao conforms to its own nature.</br>"
    }},

{passage : {
        chapterNum : "26",
        poem : "The solid must be the root of the light.</br>"+
"The still must be the master of the restless.</br>"+
"Therefore, wise people when travelling all day</br>"+
"do not lose sight of their baggage cart. Although there are beautiful scenes to see,</br>"+
"they remain quietly in their own place.</br>"+
" Should a lord of ten thousand chariots appear more frivolous than a simple traveller?</br>"+
" To be light is to lose the root. To be restless is to lose the master.</br>"
    }},

{passage : {
        chapterNum : "27",
        poem : "Good traveling leaves no tracks;</br>"+
"Good speech is without reproach;</br>"+
"Good strategies need no plotting;</br>"+
"With good fastening, even a door with no hinge cannot be opened;</br>"+
"The good knot is made without a rope and cannot be unravelled.</br>"+
"Hence the Sage never fails in saving people, Therefore no one is rejected;</br>"+
"The Sage never fails at saving things, Therefore nothing is left abandoned, This is illumination.</br>"+
"Thus the good people are the teachers of the bad;</br>"+
"The bad people are resources for the good. One who fails to respect his teacher, And does not cherish his resources,</br>"+
"However intelligent such a one may be, he is still greatly confused. This is the essential mystery!</br>"
    }},

{passage : {
        chapterNum : "28",
        poem : "Develop the strength of a man, but live as gently as a woman.</br>"+
        "Become a brook and receive all things under heaven.</br>"+
"If you are such a brook then Virtue will constantly flow into you and you will become a simple child again.</br>"+
"Know the pure but live the life of the sullied.</br>"+
"Become a fountain to all things under heaven.</br>"+
"If you become such a fountain then you will have abundant Virtue and you will return to the state of the Uncarved Block.</br>"+
"When the Uncarved Block is cut up into pieces, it is turned into specialised instruments.</br>"+
"But the True Person makes use of it whole and becomes the master of the instruments.</br>"+
"Hence, it is said, The finest carver cuts little.</br>"
    }},

{passage : {
        chapterNum : "29",
        poem : "Whoever wishes to take over the world will not succeed.</br>"+
"The world is a sacred vessel and nothing should be done to it.</br>"+
"Whoever tries to tamper with it will mar it. Whoever tries to grab it will lose it.</br>"+
"Hence, there is a time to go ahead and a time to stay behind.</br>"+
"There is a time to breathe easy and a time to breathe hard.</br>"+
"\There is a time to be vigorous and a time to be gentle.</br>"+
"There is a time to gather and a time to release.</br>"+
"Therefore, the True Person avoids extremes, self-indulgence, and extravagance.</br>"
    }},

{passage : {
        chapterNum : "30",
        poem : "If you would assist leaders of people by way of the Tao, you will oppose the use of armed force to overpower the world.</br>"+
"Those who use weapons will be harmed by them.</br>"+
"Where troops have camped only thorn bushes grow.</br>"+
"Bad harvests follow in the wake of a great army.</br>"+
"The skilful person strikes the blow and stops, without taking advantage of victory.</br>"+
"Bring it to a conclusion but do not be vain.</br>"+
"Bring it to a conclusion but do not be boastful. Bring it to a conclusion but do not be arrogant.</br>"+
"Bring it to a conclusion but only when there is no choice. Bring it to a conclusion but without violence.</br>"+
"When force is used, youthful strength decays. This is not the way of Tao. And that which goes against the Tao will quickly pass away</br>"
    }},

{passage : {
        chapterNum : "31",
        poem : "Weapons are ill-omened things.</br>"+
"Among gentle people the left side is the place of honour when at home, but in war the right side is the place of honour.</br>"+
"Weapons are not proper instruments for gentle people; they use them only when they have no other choice.</br>"+
"Peace and quiet are what they value. They do not glory in victory.</br>"+
"to glorify it is to delight in the slaughter of people. Those who delight in the slaughter of people will never thrive among all that dwell under heaven.</br>"+
"The army that has killed people should be received with sorrow. Conquerors should be received with the rites of mourning.</br>"
    }},

{passage : {
        chapterNum : "32",
        poem : "The Art of the Dao is nameless.</br>"+
"Though the Uncarved Block is small, it is not inferior to anything under heaven.</br>"+
"If leaders could keep hold of it, the ten thousand things would submit to them freely.</br>"+
"Heaven and earth would unite and sweet dew would fall.</br>"+
"The people would live in harmony without any law or decree.</br>"+
"Only when the Block is carved are there names.</br>"+
"As soon as there are names it is time to stop.Knowing when to stop prevents trouble. </br>"+
"All under heaven will return to the Tao as brooks and streams flow home to the sea.</br>"
    }},

{passage : {
        chapterNum : "33",
        poem : "Knowing people is being intelligent, Knowing self is being enlightened.</br>"+
"Victorious over people is being powerful, Victorious over self is being invincible.</br>"+
"Those who are content are submerged in wealth, Those who are contentious are submitted to ambitions,</br>"+
"Those who do not forget their principles endure, Those who die but are not forgotten live on.</br>"
    }},

{passage : {
        chapterNum : "34",
        poem : "The great Tao covers everything like a flood.</br>"+
"It flows to the left and to the right.</br>"+
"The ten thousand things depend upon it and it denies none of them.</br>"+
"It accomplishes its task yet claims no reward. It clothes and feeds the ten thousand things yet it does not attempt to control them.</br>"+
"Therefore, it may be called the little.</br>"+
"The ten thousand things return to it, even though it does not control them. Therefore, it may be called the great.</br>"+
"So it is that the True Person does not wish to be great and therefore becomes truly great.</br>"
    }},

{passage : {
        chapterNum : "35",
        poem : "Hold on to the Great Image and all under heaven will approach you.</br>"+
"Coming to you and not being harmed, they will find rest, peace, and security.</br>"+
"A passing guest will pause at the sound of music and the smell of fancy food.</br>"+
"By comparison the Tao is mild and flavourless. It is not solid enough to be seen, nor loud enough to be heard. Yet, it lasts forever.</br>"
    }},

{passage : {
        chapterNum : "36",
        poem : "That which is to be shrunk must first be stretched out.</br>"+
"That which is to be weakened must first be strengthened.</br>"+
"That which is to be cast down must first be raised up.</br>"+
"That which is to be taken must first be given.</br>"+
"There is wisdom in dimming your light. For the soft and gentle will overcome the hard and powerful.</br>"+
"Fish are best left in deep waters. And, weapons are best kept out of sight.</br>"
    }},

{passage : {
        chapterNum : "37",
        poem : "The Tao never strives, yet nothing is left undone.</br>"+
"If leaders were able to adhere to it the ten thousand things would develop of their own accord.</br>"+
"If after they have developed they experience desires to strive, they can bury those desires under the nameless Uncarved Block.</br>"+
"The nameless Uncarved Block can protect against desire. When desires are restrained there will be peace, and then all under heaven will be at rest.</br>"
    }},

{passage : {
        chapterNum : "38",
        poem : "A person of high virtue is not conscious of virtue and therefore possesses Virtue.</br>"+
"A person of little virtue tries to be virtuous and therefore lacks Virtue.</br>"+
"A person of high virtue does not make a fuss and is not seen. A person of little virtue always makes a fuss and is always seen.</br>"+
"A truly good person functions without ulterior motive. A moralist acts out of private desires.</br>"+
"A ritualist acts and, when no one responds, rolls up a sleeve and marches.</br>"+
"When we lose the Tao, we turn to Virtue. When we lose Virtue, we turn to kindness. When we lose kindness, we turn to morality. When we lose morality, we turn to ritual.</br>"+
"Ritual is the mere husk of good faith and loyalty and the beginning of disorder.</br>"+
"Knowledge of what is to come may be a flower of the Tao, but it is the beginning of folly.</br>"+
"Hence, the well-formed person relies on what is solid and not on what is flimsy, on the fruit and not the flower.</br>"+
"Therefore, such a person lets go of that without and is content with this within.</br>"
    }},

{passage : {
        chapterNum : "39",
        poem : "From ancient times these things have arisen from the One:</br>"+
"Heaven is clear because of the One, The earth is firm because of the One,</br>"+
"The Spirit is strong because of the One, The valley is full because of the One,</br>"+
"The ten thousand things reproduce because of the One, Leaders are able to lead because of the One.</br>"+
"All of this comes from the One.</br>"+
"If heaven were not clear it would soon split.</br>"+
"If the earth were not firm it would soon bend and break.</br>"+
"If the Spirit were not strong it would soon wear out.</br>"+
"If the valley were not full it would soon dry up.</br>"+
"If the ten thousand things did not reproduce they would soon die out.</br>"+
"If leaders could not lead they would soon fall.</br>"+
"Therefore, greatness has its source in the little.</br>"+
"The low is the foundation of the high.</br>"+
"Princes call themselves alone, helpless, worthless. Is this not acknowledging a humble root?</br>"+
"Enumerate the parts of a carriage and you have not defined a carriage.</br>"+
"Better to resound like stone chimes than to tinkle like jade bells.</br>"
    }},

{passage : {
        chapterNum : "40",
        poem : "Resilience is the Dao in action,</br>"+
"Vulnerability is the Dao in expression.</br>"+
"The myriad things in the universe are conceived by existence,</br>"+
"Existence is conceived by inexistence.</br>"
    }},

{passage : {
        chapterNum : "41",
        poem : "The wise student on hearing the Tao diligently puts it into practice.</br>"+
"The average student on hearing the Tao keeps it one minute and loses it the next.</br>"+
"The mediocre student on hearing the Tao laughs at it loudly. If this student did not laugh it would not be the Tao.</br>"+
"Therefore, the ancient proverb says: The bright path seems dull. The path that goes toward seems to lead backward.</br>"+
"The even path seems up and down. The greatest whiteness seems soiled. </br>"+
"High Virtue seems like a canyon. Abundant Virtue seems deficient. Vigorous Virtue seems limp. Simple Virtue seems faded.</br>"+
"The greatest square has no corners. The greatest vessel takes long to complete.The greatest note is hard to hear. The greatest image has no shape. </br>"+
"The Tao is hidden and nameless; yet, it is the Tao alone that supports all things and brings them to completion.</br>"
    }},

{passage : {
        chapterNum : "42",
        poem : "The Dao provisions unity, Unity provisions duality,</br>"+
"Duality provisions trinity,Trinity gives birth to the ten thousand things.</br>"+
"The ten thousand things have their backs in the shadow while they embrace the light. Harmony is achieved by blending the breaths of these two forces.</br>"+
"People dislike the words alone, helpless, worthless, yet this is how Princes describe themselves.</br>"+
"So it is that sometimes a thing is increased by being diminished and diminished by being increased.</br>"+
"What others teach I also teach: A violent person will not die a natural death. I shall make this the basis of my teaching.</br>"
    }},

{passage : {
        chapterNum : "43",
        poem : "The most yielding of all things overcomes the hardest of all things.</br>"+
"That which has no substance enters where there is no crevice.</br>"+
"Hence, I know the value of action without striving.</br>"+
"Few things under heaven bring more benefit than the lessons learned from silence and the actions taken without striving.</br>"
    }},

{passage : {
        chapterNum : "44",
        poem : "Your integrity or your body: Which is more important?</br>"+
"Your body or your possessions: Which is worth more?</br>"+
"Gain or loss: Which is more harmful?</br>"+
"Thus it is that the miser will pay much. The hoarder will suffer great loss.</br>"+
"Be content with what you have and you will not be disgraced. </br>"+
"Know when to stop and you will be preserved from danger.</br>"+
"Only in this way will you long endure.</br>"
    }},

{passage : {
        chapterNum : "45",
        poem : "Great accomplishment seems incomplete, yet its use is not impaired.</br>"+
"Great fullness seems empty, yet it will never be drained.</br>"+
"Great straightness looks crooked. Great skill appears clumsy. Great eloquence sounds like stammering.</br>"+
"Movement overcomes cold, stillness overcomes heat. </br>"+
"The calm and quiet set right everything under heaven.</br>"
    }},

{passage : {

{passage : {

{passage : {

{passage : {

{passage : {

{passage : {

{passage : {

"天門開闔，</br>"+
"能為雌乎？</br>"+
"明白四達，</br>"+
"能無爲乎？</br>"+
"生之畜之，</br>"+
"生而不有，</br>"+
"為而不恃，</br>"+
"長而不宰，</br>"+
"是謂玄德 。</br>"
    }},

{passage : {
        chapterNum : "第十一章",
        poem : "三十輻共一轂，</br>"+
"當其無，有車之用。</br>"+
"埏埴以為器，</br>"+
"當其無，有器之用。</br>"+
"鑿戶牖以為室，</br>"+
"當其無，有室之用。</br>"+
"故有之以為利，</br>"+
"無之以為用。</br>"
    }},

{passage : {
        chapterNum : "第十二章",
        poem : "五色令人目盲，</br>"+
"五音令人耳聾，</br>"+
"五味令人口爽，</br>"+
"馳騁畋獵令人心發狂，</br>"+
"難得之貨令人行妨。</br>"+
"是以聖人為腹不為目，</br>"+
"故去彼取此。</br>"
    }},

{passage : {
        chapterNum : "第十三章",
        poem : "寵辱若驚，</br>"+
"貴大患若身。</br>"+
"何謂寵辱若驚？</br>"+
"寵為下。</br>"+
"得之若驚，失之若驚，</br>"+
"是謂寵辱若驚。</br>"+
"何謂貴大患若身？</br>"+
"吾所以有大患者，為吾有身；</br>"+
"及吾無身，吾有何患？</br>"+
"故貴以身為天下，</br>"+
"若可寄天下。</br>"+
"愛以身為天下，</br>"+
"若可託天下。</br>"
    }},

{passage : {
        chapterNum : "第十四章",
        poem : "視之不見，名曰夷；</br>"+
"聽之不聞，名曰希；</br>"+
"摶之不得，名曰微。</br>"+
"此三者不可致詰，故混而為一。</br>"+
"其上不皦，其下不昧，</br>"+
"繩繩不可名，復歸於無物，</br>"+
"是謂無狀之狀，無物之象，</br>"+
"是謂惚恍。</br>"+
"迎之不見其首，隨之不見其後。</br>"+
"執今之道以御今之有，能知古始，</br>"+
"是謂道紀。</br>"
    }},

{passage : {
        chapterNum : "第十五章",
        poem : "古之善為道者，微妙</br>"+
"玄達，深不可識。</br>"+
"夫唯不可識，故強為之容。</br>"+
"豫兮，若冬涉川；</br>"+
"猶兮，若畏四鄰；</br>"+
"儼兮，其若客；</br>"+
"渙兮，若冰之將釋；</br>"+
"敦兮，其若樸；</br>"+
"曠兮，其若谷；</br>"+
"渾兮，其若濁。</br>"+
"孰能濁以靜之徐清。</br>"+
"孰能安以動之徐生。</br>"+
"保此道不欲盈。</br>"+
"夫唯不盈，故能蔽而新成。</br>"
    }},

{passage : {
        chapterNum : "第十六章",
        poem : "致虛極；守靜篤。</br>"+
"萬物並作，</br>"+
"吾以觀復。</br>"+
"夫物芸芸，各復歸其根，</br>"+
"歸根曰靜，</br>"+
"是謂復命；</br>"+
"復命曰常，</br>"+
"知常曰明。</br>"+
"不知常妄作，凶。</br>"+
"知常容。</br>"+
"容乃公，</br>"+
"公乃王，</br>"+
"王乃天，</br>"+
"天乃道，</br>"+
"道乃久，</br>"+
"沒身不殆。</br>"
}},

 {passage : {
        chapterNum : "第十七章",
        poem : "太上，下知有之；</br>"+
"其次，親而譽之；</br>"+
"其次畏之；</br>"+
"其次侮之。</br>"+
"信不足焉，有不信焉。</br>"+
"悠兮，其貴言，</br>"+
"功成事遂，</br>"+
"百姓皆謂我自然。</br>"
    }},

{passage : {
        chapterNum : "第十八章",
        poem : "大道廢，有仁義；</br>"+
"智慧出，有大偽；</br>"+
"六親不和有孝慈，</br>"+
"國家昏亂有忠臣。</br>"
    }},

{passage : {
        chapterNum : "第十九章",
        poem : "絕聖棄智，民利百倍；</br>"+
"絕仁棄義，民復孝慈；</br>"+
"絕巧棄利，盜賊無有；</br>"+
"此三者，以為文不足，</br>"+
"故令有所屬：</br>"+
"見素抱樸，</br>"+
"少私寡欲。</br>"
    }},

{passage : {
        chapterNum : "第二十章",
        poem : "絕學無憂。</br>"+
"唯之與阿，相去幾何？</br>"+
"善之與惡，相去何若？</br>"+
"人之所畏，不可不畏？</br>"+
"荒兮其未央哉！</br>"+
"眾人熙熙，</br>"+
"如享太牢，</br>"+
"如登春臺。</br>"+
"我獨泊兮其未兆，</br>"+
"若嬰兒之未孩，</br>"+
"乘乘兮若無所歸。</br>"+
"眾人皆有餘，</br>"+
"而我獨若遺。</br>"+
"我愚人之心也哉！沌沌兮！</br>"+
"俗人昭昭，我獨昏昏；</br>"+
"俗人察察，我獨悶悶。</br>"+
"忽兮其若晦，</br>"+
"寂兮似無所止。</br>"+
"眾人皆有以，我獨頑且鄙。</br>"+
"我獨異於人，</br>"+
"而貴求食於母。</br>"
    }},

{passage : {
        chapterNum : "第二十一章",
        poem : "孔德之容，</br>"+
"唯道是從。</br>"+
"道之為物，</br>"+
"惟恍惟惚。</br>"+
"惚兮恍其中有象；</br>"+
"恍兮惚其中有物。</br>"+
"窈兮冥兮，</br>"+
"其中有精；</br>"+
"其精甚真，其中有信。</br>"+
"自古及今，</br>"+
"其名不去，</br>"+
"以閱眾甫。</br>"+
"吾何以知眾甫之然哉？</br>"+
"以此。</br>"
    }},

{passage : {
        chapterNum : "第二十二章",
        poem : "曲則全，</br>"+
"枉則直，</br>"+
"窪則盈，</br>"+
"弊則新，</br>"+
"少則得，</br>"+
"多則惑，</br>"+
"是以聖人抱一，</br>"+
"為天下式。</br>"+
"不自見故明，</br>"+
"不自伐故彰，</br>"+
"不自是故有功，</br>"+
"不自矜故長。</br>"+
"夫惟不爭，</br>"+
"故天下莫能與之爭。</br>"+
"古之所謂曲則全者，</br>"+
"豈虛言哉！</br>"+
"誠全而歸之。</br>"
    }},

{passage : {
        chapterNum : "第二十三章",
        poem : "希言自然。</br>"+
"故飄風不終朝，</br>"+
"驟雨不終日。</br>"+
"孰為此者？</br>"+
"天地尚不能久，</br>"+
"而況於人乎？</br>"+
"故從事於道者，</br>"+
"道者同於道，</br>"+
"德者同於德，</br>"+
"失者同於失。</br>"+
"同於道者，道亦樂得之；</br>"+
"同於德者，德亦樂得之；</br>"+
"同於失者，失亦樂得之。</br>"+
"信不足焉，</br>"+
"有不信焉。</br>"
    }},

{passage : {
        chapterNum : "第二十四章",
        poem : "跂者不立，</br>"+
"跨者不行，</br>"+
"自見者不明，</br>"+
"自是者不彰。</br>"+
"自伐者無功，</br>"+
"自矜者不長。</br>"+
"其在道也，</br>"+
"曰餘食贅行。</br>"+
"物或惡之，</br>"+
"故有道者不處也。</br>"
    }},

{passage : {
        chapterNum : "第二十五章",
        poem : "有物混成，</br>"+
"先天地生，</br>"+
"寂兮寥兮，</br>"+
"獨立而不改，</br>"+
"周行而不殆，</br>"+
"可以為天下母。</br>"+
"吾不知其名，</br>"+
"字之曰道，</br>"+
"強為之名曰大。</br>"+
"大曰逝，</br>"+
"逝曰遠。</br>"+
"遠曰反。</br>"+
"故道大，</br>"+
"天大，</br>"+
"地大，</br>"+
"王亦大。</br>"+
"域中有四大，</br>"+
"而王處一焉。</br>"+
"人法地，</br>"+
"地法天，</br>"+
"天法道，</br>"+
"道法自然。</br>"
    }},

{passage : {
        chapterNum : "第二十六章",
        poem : "重為輕根，</br>"+
"靜為躁君，</br>"+
"是以君子終日行不離輜重；</br>"+
"雖有榮觀，</br>"+
"燕處超然。</br>"+
"奈何以萬乘之主，</br>"+
"而身輕天下？</br>"+
"輕則失臣，</br>"+
"躁則失君。</br>"
    }},

{passage : {
        chapterNum : "第二十七章",
        poem : "善行，無轍跡；</br>"+
"善言，無瑕謫；</br>"+
"善計，不用籌策；</br>"+
"善閉，無關鍵而不可開；</br>"+
"善結，無繩約而不可解。</br>"+
"是以聖人常善救人，</br>"+
"故無棄人；</br>"+
"善救物，</br>"+
"故無棄物，</br>"+
"是謂襲明。</br>"+
"故善人，不善人之師；</br>"+
"不善人，善人之資。</br>"+
"不貴其師，</br>"+
"不愛其資，</br>"+
"雖智大迷。</br>"+
"是謂要妙。</br>"
    }},

{passage : {
        chapterNum : "第二十八章",
        poem : "知其雄，</br>"+
"守其雌，</br>"+
"為天下谿。</br>"+
"為天下谿，常德不離，</br>"+
"復歸於嬰兒。</br>"+
"知其白，</br>"+
"守其黑，</br>"+
"為天下式。</br>"+
"為天下式，常德不忒，</br>"+
"復歸於無極。</br>"+
"知其榮，</br>"+
"守其辱，</br>"+
"為天下谷。</br>"+
"為天下谷，常德乃足，</br>"+
"復歸於朴。</br>"+
"朴散則為器，</br>"+
"聖人用之則為官長。</br>"+
"故大制不割。</br>"
    }},

{passage : {
        chapterNum : "第二十九章",
        poem : "將欲取天下而為之，</br>"+
"吾見其不得已。</br>"+
"天下神器，</br>"+
"不可為也。</br>"+
"為者敗之，</br>"+
"執者失之。</br>"+
"故物或行或隨，</br>"+
"或呴或吹，</br>"+
"或強或羸，</br>"+
"或載或隳。</br>"+
"是以聖人去甚。</br>"+
"去奢、去泰。</br>"
    }},

{passage : {
        chapterNum : "第三十章",
        poem : "以道佐人主者，</br>"+
"不以兵強天下，</br>"+
"其事好還。</br>"+
"師之所處，荊棘生焉。</br>"+
"大軍之後，必有凶年。</br>"+
"故善者果而已矣，</br>"+
"不敢以取強。</br>"+
"果而勿矜，</br>"+
"果而勿伐，</br>"+
"果而勿驕，</br>"+
"果而不得已，</br>"+
"果而勿強。</br>"+
"物壯則老，</br>"+
"是謂不道，</br>"+
"不道早已。</br>"
    }},

{passage : {
        chapterNum : "第三十一章",
        poem : "夫佳兵者，不祥之器，</br>"+
"物或惡之，</br>"+
"故有道者不處。</br>"+
"是以君子居則貴左，</br>"+
"用兵則貴右。</br>"+
"兵者，不祥之器，</br>"+
"非君子之器。</br>"+
"不得已而用之，</br>"+
"恬淡為上，</br>"+
"勝而不美；</br>"+
"而美之者，是樂殺人也。</br>"+
"夫樂殺人者，</br>"+
"不可得志於天下矣。</br>"+
"故吉事尚左，</br>"+
"凶事尚右。</br>"+
"是以偏將軍處左，</br>"+
"上將軍處右，</br>"+
"以喪禮處之。</br>"+
"殺人之眾，以悲哀蒞之。</br>"+
"戰勝，以喪禮處之。</br>"
    }},

{passage : {
        chapterNum : "第三十二章",
        poem : "道常無名。</br>"+
"朴雖小，</br>"+
"天下不敢臣。</br>"+
"候王若能守，</br>"+
"萬物將自賓。</br>"+
"天地相合，</br>"+
"以降甘露，</br>"+
"人莫之令而自均。</br>"+
"始制有名；</br>"+

"知止所以不殆。</br>"+
"譬道之在天下，</br>"+
"由川谷之於江海。</br>"
    }},

{passage : {
        chapterNum : "第三十三章",
        poem : "知人者智，</br>"+
"自知者明。</br>"+
"勝人者有力，</br>"+
"自勝者強。</br>"+
"知足者富，</br>"+
"強行者有志，</br>"+
"不失其所者久，</br>"+
"死而不亡者壽。</br>"
    }},

{passage : {
        chapterNum : "第三十四章",
        poem : "大道汎兮，</br>"+
"其可左右。</br>"+
"萬物恃之以生而不辭，</br>"+
"功成不名有。</br>"+
"衣被萬物而不為主，</br>"+
"常無欲，</br>"+
"可名於小；</br>"+
"萬物歸焉而不為主，</br>"+
"可名於大。</br>"+
"是以聖人終不為大，</br>"+
"故能成其大。</br>"
    }},

{passage : {
        chapterNum : "第三十五章",
        poem : "執大象，</br>"+
"天下往；</br>"+
"往而不害，</br>"+
"安平泰。</br>"+
"樂與餌，</br>"+
"過客止。</br>"+
"道之出口，</br>"+
"淡乎無味，</br>"+
"視之不可見，</br>"+
"聽之不可聞，</br>"+
"用之不可既。</br>"
    }},

{passage : {
        chapterNum : "第三十六章",
        poem : "將欲歙之，必固張之；</br>"+
"將欲弱之，必固強之；</br>"+
"將欲廢之，必固興之；</br>"+
"將欲奪之，必固與之。</br>"+
"是謂微明，</br>"+
"柔勝剛弱勝強。</br>"+
"魚不可脫於淵，</br>"+
"國之利器不可以示人。</br>"
    }},

{passage : {
        chapterNum : "第三十七章",
        poem : "道常無為而無不為。</br>"+
"侯王若能守，</br>"+
"萬物將自化；</br>"+
"化而欲作，</br>"+
"吾將鎮之以無名之樸；</br>"+
"無名之樸，亦將不欲；</br>"+
"不欲以靜，</br>"+
"天下將自正。</br>"
    }},

{passage : {
        chapterNum : "第三十八章",
        poem : "上德不德，</br>"+
"是以有德；</br>"+
"下德不失德，</br>"+
"是以無德。</br>"+
"上德無為而無以為，</br>"+
"下德為之而有以為。</br>"+
"上仁為之而無以為。</br>"+
"上義為之而有以為。</br>"+
"上禮為之而莫之應，</br>"+
"則攘臂而仍之。</br>"+
"故失道而後德，</br>"+
"失德而後仁，</br>"+
"失仁而後義，</br>"+
"失義而後禮。</br>"+
"夫禮者，</br>"+
"忠信之薄而亂之首也；</br>"+
"前識者，</br>"+
"道之華而愚之始也。</br>"+
"是以大丈夫處其厚，</br>"+
"不處其薄；</br>"+
"居其實，不居其華。</br>"+
"故去彼取此。</br>"
    }},

{passage : {
        chapterNum : "第三十九章",
        poem : "昔之得一者：</br>"+
"天得一以清，</br>"+
"地得一以靈，</br>"+
"神得一以寧，</br>"+
"谷得一以盈，</br>"+
"萬物得一以生，</br>"+
"侯王得一以為天下貞，</br>"+
"其致之一也。</br>"+
"天無以清，將恐裂；</br>"+
"地無以寧，將恐發；</br>"+
"神無以靈，將恐歇；</br>"+
"谷無以盈，將恐竭；</br>"+
"萬物無以生，將恐滅；</br>"+
"侯王無以貞貴高，</br>"+
"將恐蹙。</br>"+
"故貴以賤為本，</br>"+
"高以下為基。</br>"+
"侯王自謂孤、寡不榖。</br>"+
"此其以賤為本也？非乎？</br>"+
"故致數車無車。</br>"+
"不欲琭琭如玉，</br>"+
"落落如石。</br>"
    }},

{passage : {
        chapterNum : "第四十章",
        poem : "反者道之動，</br>"+
"弱者道之用。</br>"+
"天下萬物生於有，</br>"+
"有生於無。</br>"
    }},

{passage : {
        chapterNum : "第四十一章",
        poem : "上士聞道，勤而行之；</br>"+
"中士聞道，若存若亡；</br>"+
"下士聞道，大笑之，</br>"+

"明道若昧，</br>"+
"進道若退，</br>"+
"夷道若類，</br>"+
"上德若谷，</br>"+
"大白若辱，</br>"+
"廣德若不足，</br>"+
"建德若偷，</br>"+
"質直若渝，</br>"+
"大方無隅，</br>"+
"大器晚成，</br>"+
"大音希聲，</br>"+
"大象無形。</br>"+
"夫惟道，善貸且成。</br>"
    }},

{passage : {
        chapterNum : "第四十二章",
        poem : "道生一，</br>"+
"一生二，</br>"+
"二生三，</br>"+
"三生萬物。</br>"+
"萬物負陰而抱陽，</br>"+
"沖氣以為和。</br>"+
"(人之所惡，</br>"+
"孤、寡、不榖，</br>"+
"而王公以為稱。)</br>"+
"故物，或損之而益，</br>"+
"或益之而損。</br>"+
"人之所教，我亦教之：</br>"+
"強梁者不得其死，</br>"+
"吾將以為教父。</br>"
    }},

{passage : {
        chapterNum : "第四十三章",
        poem : "天下之至柔，</br>"+
"馳騁天下之至堅，</br>"+
"無有入於無間，</br>"+
"吾是以知無為之有益。</br>"+
"不言之教，</br>"+
"無為之益，</br>"+
"天下希及之。</br>"
    }},

{passage : {
        chapterNum : "第四十四章",
        poem : "名與身孰親？</br>"+
"身與貨孰多？</br>"+
"得與亡孰病？</br>"+
"是故甚愛必大費，</br>"+
"多藏必厚亡。</br>"+
"知足不辱，</br>"+
"知止不殆，可以長久。</br>"
    }},

{passage : {
        chapterNum : "第四十五章",
        poem : "大成若缺, </br>"+
"其用不敝；</br>"+
"大盈若沖，</br>"+
"其用不窮。</br>"+
"大直若屈，</br>"+
"大巧若拙，</br>"+
"大辯若訥。</br>"+
"躁勝寒，</br>"+
"靜勝熱，</br>"+
"清靜為天下正。</br>"
    }},

{passage : {
        chapterNum : "第四十六章",
        poem : "天下有道，</br>"+
"卻走以糞；</br>"+
"天下無道，</br>"+
"戎馬生於郊。</br>"+
"罪莫大於可欲，</br>"+
"禍莫大於不知足，</br>"+
"咎莫大於欲得。</br>"+
"故知之足，常足。</br>"
    }},

{passage : {
        chapterNum : "第四十七章",
        poem : "天下有道，</br>"+
"不出戶，</br>"+
"知天下；</br>"+
"不窺牖，</br>"+
"見天道。</br>"+
"其出彌遠，其知彌少。</br>"+
"是以聖人不行而知，</br>"+
"不見而名，</br>"+
"不為而成。</br>"
    }},

{passage : {
        chapterNum : "第四十八章",
        poem : "為學日益，</br>"+
"為道日損；</br>"+
"損之又損，</br>"+
"以至於無為；</br>"+
"無為而無不為矣。</br>"+
"故取天下者，</br>"+
"常以無事；</br>"+
"及其有事，</br>"+
"不足以取天下。</br>"
    }},

{passage : {
        chapterNum : "第四十九章",
        poem : "聖人無常心，</br>"+
"以百姓心為心。</br>"+
"善者吾善之，</br>"+
"不善者吾亦善之。</br>"+
"德善矣，</br>"+
"信者吾信之，</br>"+
"不信者吾亦信之，</br>"+
"德信矣。</br>"+
"聖人在天下惵惵，</br>"+
"為天下渾其心。</br>"+
"百姓皆注其耳目，</br>"+
"聖人皆孩之。</br>"
    }},

{passage : {
        chapterNum : "第五十章",
        poem : "出生入死。</br>"+
"生之徒十有三；</br>"+
"死之徒十有三，</br>"+
"民之生，動之死地，</br>"+
"亦十有三。</br>"+
"夫何故？</br>"+
"以其生生之厚。</br>"+
"蓋聞善攝生者，</br>"+
"陸行不遇兕虎，</br>"+
"入軍不被甲兵；</br>"+
"兕無所投其角，</br>"+
"虎無所措其爪，</br>"+
"兵無所容其刃。</br>"+
"夫何故？</br>"+
"以其無死地。</br>"
    }},

{passage : {
        chapterNum : "第五十一章",
        poem : "道生之，</br>"+
"德畜之，</br>"+
"物形之，</br>"+
"勢成之。</br>"+
"是以萬物</br>"+
"莫不尊道而貴德。</br>"+
"道之尊，</br>"+
"德之貴，</br>"+
"夫莫之命而常自然。</br>"+
"故道生之德畜之，</br>"+
"長之育之，</br>"+
"成之熟之，</br>"+
"養之復之；</br>"+
"生而不有，</br>"+
"為而不恃，</br>"+
"長而不宰，</br>"+
"是謂玄德。</br>"
    }},

{passage : {
        chapterNum : "第五十二章",
        poem : "天下有始以為天下母。</br>"+
"既得其母，</br>"+
"以知其子；</br>"+
"既知其子，</br>"+
"復守其母，</br>"+
"沒身不殆。</br>"+
"塞其兌，</br>"+
"閉其門，</br>"+
"終身不勤。</br>"+
"開其兌，</br>"+
"濟其事，</br>"+
"終身不救。</br>"+
"見小曰明，</br>"+
"守柔曰強。</br>"+
"用其光，</br>"+
"復歸其明，</br>"+
"無遺身殃，</br>"+
"是謂習常。</br>"
    }},

{passage : {
        chapterNum : "第五十三章",
        poem : "使我介然有知，</br>"+
"行於大道，</br>"+
"惟施是畏。</br>"+
"大道甚夷，</br>"+
"而民好徑。</br>"+
"朝甚除田甚蕪，</br>"+
"倉甚虛，</br>"+
"服文綵，</br>"+
"帶利劍，</br>"+
"厭飲食，</br>"+
"財貨有餘，</br>"+
"是謂盜夸。</br>"+
"非道也哉！</br>"
    }},

{passage : {
        chapterNum : "第五十四章",
        poem : "善建者不拔，</br>"+
"善抱者不脫，</br>"+
"子孫祭祀不輟。</br>"+
"修之於身，</br>"+
"其德乃真；</br>"+
"修之於家，</br>"+
"其德乃餘；</br>"+
"修之於鄉，</br>"+
"其德乃長；</br>"+
"修之於國，</br>"+
"其德乃豐；</br>"+
"修之於天下，</br>"+
"其德乃普。</br>"+

"以家觀家，</br>"+
"以鄉觀鄉，</br>"+
"以國觀國；</br>"+
"以天下觀天下。</br>"+
"吾何以知天下之然哉？</br>"+
"以此。</br>"
    }},

{passage : {
        chapterNum : "第五十五章",
        poem : "含德之厚，</br>"+
"比於赤子。</br>"+
"毒蟲不螫，</br>"+
"猛獸不據，</br>"+
"攫鷙不博。</br>"+
"骨弱筋柔而握固。</br>"+
"未知牝牡之合而全作，</br>"+
"精之至也；</br>"+
"終日號而嗌不嗄，</br>"+
"和之至也。</br>"+
"知和曰常，</br>"+
"知常曰明，</br>"+
"益生曰祥，</br>"+
"心使氣曰強。</br>"+
"物壯則老，</br>"+
"是謂不道，</br>"+
"不道早已。</br>"
    }},

{passage : {
        chapterNum : "第五十六章",
        poem : "知者不言，</br>"+
"言者不知。</br>"+
"塞其兌，</br>"+
"閉其門，</br>"+
"挫其銳，</br>"+
"解其紛，</br>"+
"和其光，</br>"+
"同其塵，</br>"+
"是謂玄同。</br>"+
"不可得而親，</br>"+
"不可得而疏；</br>"+
"不可得而利，</br>"+
"不可得而害；</br>"+
"不可得而貴，</br>"+
"不可得而賤。</br>"+
"故為天下貴。</br>"
    }},

{passage : {
        chapterNum : "第五十七章",
        poem : "以正治國，</br>"+
"以奇用兵，</br>"+
"無事取天下。</br>"+
"吾何以知其然乎？</br>"+
"以此：</br>"+
"天下多忌諱，</br>"+
"而民彌貧；</br>"+
"民多利器，</br>"+
"國家滋昏；</br>"+
"民多技巧，</br>"+
"奇物滋起；</br>"+
"法令滋彰，</br>"+
"盜賊多有。</br>"+
"故聖人云：</br>"+
"我無為而民自化，</br>"+
"我好靜而民自正，</br>"+
"我無事而民自富，</br>"+
"我無欲而民自朴。</br>"
    }},

{passage : {
        chapterNum : "第五十八章",
        poem : "其政悶悶，</br>"+
"其民醇醇；</br>"+
"其政察察，</br>"+
"其民缺缺。</br>"+
"禍兮福所倚，</br>"+
"福兮禍所伏。</br>"+
"孰知其極？</br>"+
"其無正耶。</br>"+
"正復為奇，</br>"+
"善復為妖民之迷，</br>"+
"其日固久。</br>"+

"廉而不劌，</br>"+
"直而不肆，</br>"+
"光而不耀。</br>"
    }},

{passage : {
        chapterNum : "第五十九章",
        poem : "治人事天莫如嗇。</br>"+
"夫惟嗇，</br>"+
"是謂早服。</br>"+
"早服謂之重積德，</br>"+
"重積德則無不克，</br>"+
"無不克則莫知其極，</br>"+
"莫知其極，</br>"+
"可以有國。</br>"+
"有國之母，</br>"+
"可以長久。</br>"+
"是謂深根固蒂，</br>"+
"長生久視之道。</br>"
    }},

{passage : {
        chapterNum : "第六十章",
        poem : "治大國若烹小鮮。</br>"+

"其神不傷人；</br>"+

"聖人亦不傷人。</br>"+
"夫兩不相傷，</br>"+
"故德交歸焉。</br>"
    }},

{passage : {

        poem : "大國者下流。</br>"+

"則取小國；</br>"+

"則取大國。</br>"+

"小國小過欲入事人，</br>"+
"夫兩者各得其所欲，</br>"+
"故大者宜為下。</br>"
    }},

{passage : {
        chapterNum : "第六十二章",
        poem : "道者萬物之奧，</br>"+
"善人之寶，</br>"+
"不善人之所保。</br>"+
"美言可以巿，</br>"+
"尊行可以加人。</br>"+
"人之不善何棄之有！</br>"+
"故立天子，</br>"+
"置三公，</br>"+

"有罪以免邪？</br>"+
"故為天下貴。</br>"
    }},

{passage : {
        chapterNum : "第六十三章",
        poem : "為無為，</br>"+
"事無事，</br>"+
"味無味。</br>"+
"大小多少，</br>"+
"報怨以德。</br>"+
"圖難于其易，</br>"+
"為大于其細。</br>"+
"天下難事必作于易，</br>"+
"天下大事必作于細，</br>"+
"是以聖人終不為大，</br>"+

"夫輕諾必寡信，</br>"+
"多易必多難，</br>"+
"是以聖人猶難之。</br>"+
"故終無難。</br>"
    }},

{passage : {
        chapterNum : "第六十四章",
        poem : "其安易持，</br>"+

"其微易散。</br>"+
"為之于未有，</br>"+
"治之于未亂。</br>"+

"九層之臺起于累土；</br>"+

"為者敗之，</br>"+
"執者失之。</br>"+
"聖人無為，故無敗；</br>"+
"無執，故無失。</br>"+
"民之徒事，常于幾成而敗之。</br>"+
"慎終如始，</br>"+
"則無敗事。</br>"+
"是以聖人欲不欲，</br>"+
"不貴難得之貨。</br>"+
"學不學，</br>"+
"復眾人之所過。</br>"+
"以輔萬物之自然，</br>"+
"而不敢為。</br>"
    }},

{passage : {

        poem : "古之善為道者，</br>"+
"非以明民，</br>"+
"將以愚之。</br>"+
"民之難，</br>"+
"治以其智多。</br>"+
"以智治國，國之賊；</br>"+
"不以智治國，國之福。</br>"+
"知此兩者，亦楷式。</br>"+
"能知楷式，</br>"+
"是謂玄德。</br>"+
"玄德深矣，遠矣，</br>"+
"與物反矣，乃至于大順。</br>"
    }},

{passage : {
        chapterNum : "第六十六章",
        poem : "江海所以能為百谷王者，</br>"+

"久矣其細也夫。</br>"
    }},

{passage : {

        poem : "我有三寶，持而寶之。</br>"+

"慈，故能勇；</br>"+

"不敢為天下先，</br>"+

"以守則固，</br>"+

{passage : {

        poem : "善為士者不武，</br>"+

"善勝敵者不爭，</br>"+
"善用人者為之下</br>"+

"是謂用人之力，</br>"+
"是謂配天古之極。</br>"
    }},

{passage : {

{passage : {

"事有君。</br>"+

{passage : {

{passage : {

{passage : {

{passage : {

{passage : {

{passage : {

{passage : {

"功成而不處，</br>"+
"其不欲見賢耶。</br>"
    }},

{passage : {

        poem : "天下柔弱</br>"+

"而攻堅強者莫之能勝，</br>"+

"柔之勝剛，</br>"+
"天下莫不知，</br>"+
"莫能行。</br>"+
"故聖人云，</br>"+
"受國之垢，是謂社稷主；</br>"+

"正言若反。</br>"
    }},

{passage : {

        poem : "和大怨，</br>"+

"安可以為善？</br>"+

"而不責於人。</br>"+
"有德司契，</br>"+
"無德司徹。</br>"+
"天道無親，</br>"+
"常與善人。</br>"
